awd_titl_txt: STEM Pioneers: A 3-year pilot study to increase science literacy and STEM enrollment among first-year first-generation students
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will address the barriers that first-generation students experience in college. There is a critical need to expand the existing research to better understand how first-time, first-generation students will be enabled to enter and succeed as STEM majors. The project is unique in that it will integrate several interconnected, research-based, effective practices aimed at the specific needs of first-generation students in the sciences. Specifically the project will (1) convene a group of science professors who will work together to design and teach a science literacy course aimed at teaching not just what science is, but also why it matters to society; (2) create a group of peer mentors and mentoring activities aimed at fostering a supportive environment within which first-generation students can express their needs and have them be addressed; and (3) work with the campus advising office to select students to participate in the program and to provide additional support services such as extensive career counseling. Participants in each of these three groups will also meet with each other on a continual basis to monitor student success and the success of the different approaches taken.

The program that is envisioned has two specific objectives: (1) to increase science literacy of undeclared first-generation, first-year college students and (2) to encourage and enable students to select and successfully embark on STEM majors at the university. This project will develop a three-pronged approach that transforms and blends existing interventions into a sustained, integrative and organized structure to address the broad scope of needs of first-generation students. The first prong is a professional learning community (PLC) of faculty from a variety of science majors (biology, chemistry, math, physics, computer science, and earth and environmental science) and from English. The PLC will work together to create and teach a two-semester science literacy course for the selected first-generation students. This course will follow a broad topic in science such as global climate change or water availability and study it from the perspectives of the different scientific disciplines of the PLC faculty. Students will be guided in developing a research project on this topic. The second prong places selected first-generation students in student learning communities (SLC) where they take the same courses together. A goal of the SLC will be to create shared experiences and bonding between the students and faculty. The third prong focuses on advising and mentoring, and will be accomplished by employing professional advisors, peer mentors, and organizing advising sessions that will cover topics ranging from course and major selection to career opportunities. A framework will be established to allow constant interaction between all three of these components. Very important to the success of this project will be an assessment that will look at the success of each component individually and as a whole. A goal will be to figure out how to successfully increase first-generation students' recruitment into the sciences and enhance their academic and professional success once they have chosen a science major. A well-qualified evaluator and statistical consultant will assess the project through the use of a comparison group.

por.por_cntn:
STEM Pioneers Project Outcomes report. 1611989

 

Almost all major debates at the local and national levels, including those over how to best manage our resources and to live sustainably, require a basic understanding of the science behind the factors driving these decisions. We are helping society make well-informed decisions by increasing the number of members of society who are scientifically literate. We hoped to have expanded the population base that can understand and explain scientific concepts and, thus, help their communities be involved in making informed decisions. Increasing science literacy in this population of students may have further positive effects on science literacy skills in their families and communities. This has become even more critical given the current pandemic situation. To this end we created the STEM Pioneers program within the College of Science and Mathematics at Montclair State University, Montclair, NJ.

 

By creating a program that supported first-generation students in the exploration of STEM majors, we also hoped to increase the diversity of the STEM workforce and open doors and paths for first-generation students to well-paying and intellectually-stimulating STEM careers.  Often first-generation students do not choose a STEM major and it was our goal to support them in their exploration and help them obtain the skills and confidence to pursue STEM majors by the end of their year in STEM Pioneers. The program was also focused on supporting their success at the University level in general and increasing the likelihood that they would be successful and graduate, regardless of the major they choose. 

 

The major goals of the project were to work with first-year, first-generation students to 1. increase their level of scientific literacy; 2. increase their enrollment and/or retention in STEM majors at Montclair State University; and 3. increase their overall academic success. To achieve these goals we created a science literacy course that students took along with an existing writing course. We also established a peer-mentoring program to provide support outside of the classroom.

 

Our survey data show that for the first three years of the project for which we have data, the STEM Pioneers were 73.5 % women and 26.5 % men.  Of STEM Pioneers, 65.1% were African American or Hispanic. Of the students in the STEM Pioneers, 83.1 % identified as first-generation students (neither parent attended college for at least four years). Many STEM Pioneers had been exposed to other languages and cultures as 45 % of STEM Pioneers were second generation immigrants and 14 % were first generation immigrants to the United States and 57 % spoke another language in addition to English at home.  All but one STEM Pioneer were in the age range 17 – 19 and they worked an average of 12.5 hours per week at the beginning of the semester and 10.8 hours at the end of the semester.

 

Our general findings are that our program improved science literacy skills for students who came in with the lowest scientific literacy skills.  Generally, there were no discernible impacts on science literacy for the rest of the students who participated in the program during the period of our study with the exception of the ability to solve quantitative problems where we did see an improvement. There is some indication that first generation students who participated in the STEM Pioneers program had higher retention rates and GPAs than first generation students who did not participate in the program. Also, more students in the STEM Pioneers program declared a science major than first generation students who did not participate in the program. Further analysis of our data suggests that lack of financial support for students within the program may have limited the overall impact of the program on the participating students. This highlights the need for financial security to allow students to get the full benefits of their education.
